ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: INCASLIB=caslib
      
Specifies the input caslib for the procedure. This option does not change the active caslib for your session. 
If you do not specify this option here or in a statement, such as LOAD, then the active caslib is used. 

Specifying the caslib to use is a best practice until you develop experience working with the active caslib 
with this procedure, the CAS LIBNAME engine, and other procedures.

Syntax: OUTCASLIB=caslib
      
Specifies the output caslib for the procedure. This option does not change the active caslib for your session. 
If you do not specify this option here or in a statement, such as LOAD, then the active caslib is used.

Syntax: SESSREF=session-name
      
Specifies the session to use with the procedure. If you omit SESSREF=, then procedure uses the session 
that specified in the &_SESSREF_ macro variable.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: CASDATA="table-name"
          
Specifies the name of the file or table.

Syntax: IMPORTOPTIONS=(FILETYPE="file-type" <file-type-options>) 
          
Specifies the file format and options. Specify this option only if you specify a filename in the 
CASDATA= option. If you want to display metadata for an in-memory table (the result of a LOAD 
statement), then do not specify this option.

Syntax: INCASLIB=caslib

Specifies the caslib that is associated with the file or table. If specified, this option overrides 
the INCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

Syntax: DATASOURCEOPTIONS=(data-source-options) | OPTIONS=(data-source-options)

Specifies overrides for the DATASOURCE= options for the caslib. For more information, see Platform Data 
Sources and Data Connectors.

Syntax: ROWCOUNT

Specifies to include the number of rows in the results. The data source for the input caslib must be HDFS 
and you must include the filename suffix in the CASDATA= option.

Syntax: VARS=|VARLIST=((casinvardesc-1) < (casinvardesc-2) ...>) 

Specifies the variables to include. If you do not include this option, all variables are included. 

The value for casinvardesc is described in VARLIST=((casinvardesc-1) (casinvardesc-2) ...).

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: DELETESOURCE CASDATA="file-name" <INCASLIB="caslib"> <QUIET>;
      
The DELETESOURCE statement removes a file from the data source that is associated with a caslib. You do not need 
to drop an in-memory table with the same name before using this statement. 

Note: You can delete files from path-based caslibs. These are caslibs with a data source type of DNFS, HDFS, or PATH.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: CASDATA="file-name"
          
Specifies the name of the file to remove.

Syntax: INCASLIB="caslib"

Specifies the caslib that is associated with the file to remove. If specified, this option overrides 
the INCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

Syntax: QUIET
          
Suppresses error messages and avoids setting the SYSERR automatic macro variable when the specified 
table or file is not found.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: DROPTABLE CASDATA="table-name" <INCASLIB="caslib"> <QUIET>;
      
The DROPTABLE statement removes a table from memory on SAS Cloud Analytic Services.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: CASDATA="table-name"
          
Specifies the name of the table to remove from memory.

Syntax: INCASLIB="caslib"

Specifies the caslib that is associated with the table to remove. If specified, this option overrides 
the INCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

Syntax: QUIET
          
Suppresses error messages and avoids setting the SYSERR automatic macro variable when the specified 
table is not found. 

Note: This option is currently ignored for session-scope caslibs.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: LIST <FILES | TABLES> <option(s)>;
      
TThe LIST statement lists files from a caslib’s data source or in-memory tables in a caslib.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: lists the in-memory tables in a caslib.
Lists the files that are available in the caslib's data source.

Syntax: INCASLIB="caslib"

Specifies the caslib that is associated with the tables or files to list. If specified, this option 
overrides the INCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.
Specifies to exclude subdirectories from the results.

Syntax: DATASOURCEOPTIONS=(data-source-options) 


Specifies overrides for the DATASOURCE= options for the caslib. For more information, see Platform 
Data Sources and Data Connectors. 

Applies to LIST FILES

Syntax: ROWCOUNT

Specifies to include the number of rows in the results. The data source for the input caslib must be HDFS. 

Applies to LIST FILES

Syntax: SUBDIR="path" 

Specifies to list the files in the specified subdirectory.

Syntax: CASDATA="table-name"
          
Specifies a CAS table name. The table is loaded from the data source associated with the INCASLIB= option 
in the procedure statement or this LOAD statement.

Syntax: CASOUT="table-name"
          
Specifies the name to use for the in-memory table. 

Interaction: This argument is required when you use the LOAD CASDATA= or LOAD FILE= forms.  

Note: This argument does not follow or enforce SAS naming rules such as the name literal syntax.  

Tip: Some data sources support table names that exceed 32 bytes. Use this option to limit table names to 32 bytes 
so that you can access the table with the CAS LIBNAME engine.

Syntax: DATA=SAS-data-set
          
Specifies the libref and data set name to use.

Syntax: FILE=SAS-file 
          
Specifies an external file that is accessible to the SAS client host. Use this option to upload a file 
to the server and import the data. Do not use this option to import a SAS data set, use the DATA= option. 

Requirement: You must specify CASOUT=.

Syntax: APPEND

Adds the rows from the SAS data set in the DATA= argument to the end of an in-memory table. This option 
is supported with the DATA= argument only.

Syntax: COMPRESS

Specifies to compress the output table. This option is supported with the DATA= argument only.

Syntax: COPIES=integer

Specifies the number of replicate copies of the rows to make for fault tolerance. Larger values use 
more memory and can result in slower performance, but provide high availability for data in the event 
of a node failure. 

Default: 1 
Interaction: This option is ignored if the REPEAT option is also specified.

Syntax: DATASOURCEOPTIONS=|OPTIONS=(data-source-options) 

Specifies overrides for the DATASOURCE= options for the input caslib. For more information, 
see Platform Data Sources and Data Connectors.

Syntax: GROUPBY=(group-by-variable-1 <group-by-variable-2 ...>) 

Specifies the names of the variables to use for grouping results.

Syntax: IMPORTOPTIONS=(FILETYPE="file-type" <file-type-options>) 

Specifies the file format and options. 

  FILETYPE="AUTO" | "BASESAS" | "CSV" | "DTA" | "EXCEL" | "HDAT" | "LASR" | "XLS" 
    specifies the file format. AUTO attempts to determine the file type based on the filename suffix, such as .sashdat, 
    .csv, and so on. Files with a .txt suffix are imported as a CSV file. 

    Default: AUTO 

  file-type-options
    specifies options for importing the data. For more information, see Platform File Types and Data Connectors.

Syntax: INCASLIB="caslib"

Specifies the caslib that is associated with the file to load. If specified, this option overrides 
the INCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

Syntax: LABEL="string" 

Specifies a descriptive label for the table. The label can be up to 256 characters. If the label text 
contains single quotation marks, enclose the label in double quotation marks. To remove a label from 
a table, assign a blank space that is enclosed in quotation marks.

Syntax: ORDERBY=(variable-1 <variable-2 ...>) 

Specifies the variables to use for ordering observations within partitions. This parameter applies 
to partitioned tables.

Syntax: OUTCASLIB="caslib"

Specifies an alternative caslib to use for the in-memory table. If specified, this option overrides 
the OUTCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

Syntax: PROMOTE

Specifies to load the table with global scope. This makes the table available to all sessions that use 
the caslib, subject to access controls. The caslib must also have global scope.

Syntax: REPEAT

Specifies to duplicate the rows for the table on every machine of a distributed server. Making duplicate 
copies of tables can be useful in cases like a dimension table that is used in a join. This option is supported 
with the DATA= argument only and cannot be combined with the GROUPBY= option.

Syntax: REPLACE

Specifies that an in-memory table with a given name replaces an existing in-memory table with the same name.

Syntax: VARS=|VARLIST=((casinvardesc-1) < (casinvardesc-2) ...>) 

Specifies the variables to load into the table. If you do not specify this option, then all variables 
are loaded into the table. 

The value can be one or more of the following: 

  FORMAT="string" 
    specifies the format to apply to the variable. 

  FORMATTEDLENGTH=integer
    specifies the format field length plus the format precision length. 

  LABEL="string" 
    specifies the descriptive label for the variable. 

  NAME="string" 
    specifies the name for the variable. 

  NFD=integer
    specifies the format precision length. 

  NFL=integer
    specifies the format field length.

Syntax: WHERE="where-expression-1 <logical-operator where-expression-2>" 

Specifies conditions for selecting observations from the data. 

  where-expression
    is an arithmetic or logical expression that consists of a sequence of operators, operands, and SAS functions. 
    An operand is a variable, a SAS function, or a constant. An operator is a symbol that requests a comparison, 
    logical operation, or arithmetic calculation. The expression must be enclosed in single or double quotation marks. 

  logical-operator
    can be AND, AND NOT, OR, or OR NOT.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: PROMOTE CASDATA="table-name" <INCASLIB="caslib"> <CASOUT="table-name"> <OUTCASLIB="caslib"> <DROP | KEEP>;

The PROMOTE statement copies a session-scope table to global scope. 

Note: The PROMOTE statement does not include a REPLACE option. The server does not support promoting 
a session-scope table and replacing a global-scope table in one operation. You must drop the global-scope 
table first.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: CASDATA="cas-table-name"
          
Specifies the name of the in-memory table to promote.

Syntax: CASOUT="table-name"
          
Specifies the name to use for the promoted table. 

Note: This argument does not follow or enforce SAS naming rules such as the name literal syntax.  

Tip: Some data sources support table names that exceed 32 bytes. Use this option to limit table names 
to 32 bytes so that you can access the table with the CAS LIBNAME engine.

Syntax: DROP
          
Specifies to drop the session-scope table after promoting it to global scope, which is the default behavior 
and a best practice.

Syntax: INCASLIB="caslib"

Specifies the caslib with the in-memory table to promote. If specified, this option overrides the INCASLIB= 
value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

Syntax: KEEP 
          
Specifies to keep the session-scope table after promoting it to global scope. This workflow is uncommon. 
The table precedence rules are that the session-local table is accessed before a global-scope table is 
accessed.

Syntax: OUTCASLIB="caslib"

Specifies an alternative caslib to use for the promoted table. If specified, this option overrides the 
OUTCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: SAVE CASDATA="table-name" <INCASLIB ="caslib"> CASOUT="table-name"| <OUTCASLIB ="caslib"> <option(s)>;

The SAVE statement creates a permanent copy of an in-memory table. The in-memory table is saved to the 
data source that is associated with the caslib. 

Note: You can save an in-memory table to a file with path-based caslibs. These are caslibs with a data 
source type of DNFS, HDFS, or PATH.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: CASDATA="table-name"
          
Specifies the name of the in-memory table to save.

Syntax: CASOUT="file-name"
          
Specifies an alternative name for the file. A file is created in the data source that is associated 
with the caslib from the OUTCASLIB= option. By default, a .sashdat file suffix is added. If you specify 
a .csv suffix, a CSV file is saved. 

Note This argument does not follow or enforce SAS naming rules such as the name literal syntax.  

Tip: Some data sources support table names that exceed 32 bytes. Use this option to limit table names 
to 32 bytes so that you can access the table with the CAS LIBNAME engine when you load it again.

Syntax: INCASLIB="caslib"

Specifies an alternative caslib to use for the saved table. If specified, this option overrides the 
OUTCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib. .

Syntax: OUTCASLIB="caslib"

Specifies an alternative caslib to use for the saved table. If specified, this option overrides the 
OUTCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

Syntax: COMPRESS

Specifies to compress the data in the saved file.

Syntax: COPIES=integer

Specifies the number of replicate copies of the rows to make for fault tolerance. This value is ignored 
unless the output caslib data source is HDFS and you save to the SASHDAT file format. 

Default: 1

Syntax: GROUPBY=(group-by-variable-1 <group-by-variable-2 ...>) 

Specifies the names of the variables to use for partitioning the SASHDAT file.

Syntax: IMPORTOPTIONS=(FILETYPE="file-type" <file-type-options>) 

Specifies the input file format and options. Specify this option only if you want to read a file from 
the input caslib's data source and save it without loading it to memory.

  FILETYPE="AUTO" | "BASESAS" | "CSV" | "DTA" | "EXCEL" | "HDAT" | "LASR" | "XLS" 
    specifies the file format. AUTO attempts to determine the file type based on the filename suffix, such as .sashdat, 
    .csv, and so on. Files with a .txt suffix are imported as a CSV file. 

    Default: AUTO 

  file-type-options
    specifies options for importing the data. For more information, see Platform File Types and Data Connectors.

Syntax: DATASOURCEOPTIONS=|OPTIONS=(data-source-options) 

Specifies overrides for the DATASOURCE= options for the caslib. For more information, 
see Platform Data Sources and Data Connectors.

Syntax: ORDERBY=(variable-1 <variable-2 ...>) 

Specifies the variables to use for ordering observations within partitions. This parameter applies 
to partitioned tables.

Syntax: REPLACE

Specifies that a new file with a given name replaces an existing file with the same name.

Syntax: WHERE="where-expression-1 <logical-operator where-expression-2>" 

Specifies conditions for selecting observations from the data. 

  where-expression
    is an arithmetic or logical expression that consists of a sequence of operators, operands, and SAS functions. 
    An operand is a variable, a SAS function, or a constant. An operator is a symbol that requests a comparison, 
    logical operation, or arithmetic calculation. The expression must be enclosed in single or double quotation marks. 

  logical-operator
    can be AND, AND NOT, OR, or OR NOT.
